turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Data, you're not thinking about using that thing are you?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: It has occurred to me on several occasions. But I believe this may be the appropriate time.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Wait a minute. I thought you've always been afraid it would overload your neural net.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: That is true. However, I believe my growth as an artificial lifeform has reached an impasse. For thirty-four years I have endeavored to become more "human"- to grow beyond my original programming. And yet I am still unable to grasp such a simple concept as humor. This emotion chip is the only answer.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: But at the first sign of trouble, I'm going to deactivate it. Agreed?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Agreed.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I believe the beverage has provoked an emotional response.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Really? What do you feel?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I am uncertain. I have had little experience with emotions. I am unable to articulate the sensation.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I get it. I get it.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: You get what?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: During the Farpoint mission. We were on the Bridge and you told a joke. That was the punchline.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: The Farpoint mission? Data, that was seven years ago.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I know. I just got it.  It was very funny.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: I don't see a control panel, or an access port.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: It appears to be a magnetically sealed.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Data, this isn't the time.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I am sorry, but I cannot stop myself. I think something is wrong

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Data, are you all right?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I believe the emotional chip has overloaded my positronic relays.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: We better get you back to the ship  La Forge to Enterprise.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: That's it, Bridge- we're all out!

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: One minute to warp core breach.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Sensors show five life signs aboard the station, Captain.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: The station complement was nineteen.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Looks like you're stuck with emotions for a while. How do you feel?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I am quite...preoccupied with concern about Geordi.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: We all are, Data. But we're going to get him back.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I hope so, sir.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Could we access the defective coil and trigger their cloak?

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: Perhaps.  Yes! If we sent a low-level ionic pulse, it might reset the coil and engage the cloaking systems.

turns.speaker: DATA
turns.text: I have rerouted auxiliary power to the lateral thrusters- attempting to level our descent.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: All hands, brace for impact!

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Can you locate them?

turns.speaker: DEMORA
turns.text: The ships are bearing at 3-1-0 mark 2-1-5. Distance: three light years.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Signal the closest starship. We're in no condition to mount a rescue. We don't even have a full crew aboard.

turns.speaker: DEMORA
turns.text: We're within visual range of the energy distortion, Captain.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: On screen.

turns.speaker: DEMORA
turns.text: We're within range, sir.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Beam them directly to Sickbay.

turns.speaker: DEMORA
turns.text: Deck 15, section 21-alpha.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: I'll go. You have the Bridge.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: You did it, Kirk!  Damage report, Ensign.

turns.speaker: DEMORA
turns.text: There's some buckling on the starboard nacelle.  We've also got a hull breach in the Engineering section. Emergency forcefields are in place and holding.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Do you remember him?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Oh yes. I remember everyone who was on the Lakul, every face. Even the ones who didn't make it.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Guinan. It's important that you tell me what you know. We think Soran's developed a weapon...a terrible weapon. It might give him enough power to-

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Soran doesn't care about power or weapons. All he cares about is getting back to the Nexus.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: What's the "Nexus"?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: That ribbon isn't just some random energy phenomenon travelling through space. It's a doorway. It leads to another place- the Nexus. It doesn't exist in our universe and it doesn't play by the same rules either.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: What happened to you?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: I can't remember very much - what it looked like or how long I was there. But I do remember how it felt.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: It took a long time, but eventually I learned to live with it. And I began to realize that my experience in the Nexus had changed me.  I knew things about people, about events, about time.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Your "sixth sense"- I've always wondered where it came from.  And what about Soran?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Soran may still be obsessed with getting back. And if he is, he'll do anything to find that doorway again.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: But why destroy a star?  Thank you, Guinan.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Guinan, what's going on? Where am I?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: You're in the Nexus.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: This is the Nexus?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: For you. This is where you wanted to be.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: But I never had a wife, children, a home like this.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Enjoy them, Jean-Luc.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Guinan, what are you doing here? I thought you were on the Enterprise.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: I am on the Enterprise. I am also here.  Think of me as an "echo" of the person you know. A part she left behind.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Left behind?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: When the Enterprise-B beamed us off the Lakul, we were partially in the Nexus. The transporters locked on to us, but somehow everyone left a part of themselves behind.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Soran?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: All of us.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Where is he now?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Wherever he wanted to be.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: These are my children...my children.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Yeah. They're great, aren't they? You can go back and see them born, go forward and see your grandchildren. Time has no meaning here.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Guinan, can I leave the Nexus?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Why would you want to leave?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Can I?

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: Yes, where would you go?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: I told you, time has no meaning here. If you leave, you can go anywhere, any time.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I know exactly where I want to go, and when. Back to that mountaintop on Veridian III, before Soran put out the star. I have to stop him.

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: What makes you think things will be any different this time?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: You're right. I'll need help.  Guinan, will you come back with me? Together, we could-

turns.speaker: GUINAN
turns.text: I can't leave. I'm already there, remember?

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: I'm Captain John Harriman. I'd like to welcome you all aboard.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: It's our pleasure.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Well, may we have a look around?

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Please, please.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, if you'll take your seats.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Oh, of course.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Prepare to leave spacedock. Aft thrusters ahead one quarter, port and starboard at station keeping.  Captain Kirk, I'd be honored if you would give the order to get underway.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: No, no. Thank you.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: Please, I insist.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: We don't have a tractor beam.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: You left spacedock without a tractor beam?

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: It won't be installed until Tuesday.  Ensign Sulu, try generating a subspace field around the ships. That might break them free.

turns.speaker: HARRIMAN
turns.text: What about the gravimetric distortions? They'll tear us apart.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Risk is part of the game if you want to sit in that chair.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Beautiful day, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Yes, yes, it is.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: This clock, I gave this clock to Bones.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I'm from what you would consider the future; the 24th-century.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: So you're telling me this is the 24th-century, and I'm dead?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Not exactly. As I said, this is some kind of-

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Temporal nexus, yeah, I heard you.  Something's missing.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: You said history considers me dead. Who am I to argue with history?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: You're a Starfleet officer and you have a duty to-

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I don't need to be lectured by you. I was out saving the galaxy when your grandfather was still in diapers. And frankly, I think the galaxy owes me one  I was like you once- so worried about duty and obligations that I couldn't see anything past this uniform. And in the end, what did it get me? Nothing. Not this time.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: No, no, it's not. It's better.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Better?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: This is my uncle's barn in Iowa.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Antonia?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: She's not real either, is she? Nothing here is. Nothing here matters.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Captain of the Enterprise, huh?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Close to retirement?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I hadn't planned on it.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: How can I argue with the captain of the Enterprise? What was the name of that planet=8A Veridian III?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I take it the odds are against us and the situation is grim?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: You could say that.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Of course, if Spock were here, he'd say I was being an irrational, illogical human for wanting to go on a mission like that.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: I'll find a way to contact the Enterprise. You're going to be all right.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Did we do it? Did we make a difference?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Yes.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Least I could do for a captain of the Enterprise.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Oh

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: I've warned ye about that back of yours. You should have a doctor take a look at it.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I'm not going  Scotty, help me with this chute.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: What do you mean, you're not going? We promised.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: When I retired, I swore I'd never set foot on a starship again, and I meant it.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: You know, Scotty, it amazes me.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: And what would that be, sir?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Sulu. When did he find the time for a family?

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: It's like you always said- if something's important enough, you make the time.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Their life signs are are phasing in and out of our space-time continuum.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Phasing? To where?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: The first thing you learn as captain is how to cheat death.  Scotty?

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: There's just no way to disrupt a gravimetric field of this magnitude!

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: But I do have a theory...

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I thought you might.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: An anti-matter discharge directly ahead=8A it might disrupt the field long enough for us to break away.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: A photon torpedo?

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Load torpedo bays, prepare to fire on my command.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Captain, it may be possible to simulate a torpedo blast using a resonance burst from the main deflector dish.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Where are the deflector relays?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Keep her together until I get back.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: I always do.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Kirk here.

turns.speaker: SCOTTY
turns.text: Captain, I don't know how much longer I can hold her together!

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: A remarkable piece of equipment, but a little inelegant, wouldn't you say?  Have you ever considered a prosthesis that would make you look a little more...normal?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: What's normal?

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Normal is what everyone else is, and what you are not.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: I don't want a science lecture. You were on that observatory looking for trilithium. Why?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: I was ordered to by the Captain.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Let's try to move beyond the usual prisoner-interrogator banter, shall we? You have information and I need it.  Did the Captain explain his orders to you? Did he say why you were searching for trilithium?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: What about Guinan? What has she told you about me?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Guinan? I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Oh, I forgot to tell you. While you were unconscious, I injected a nano-probe into your bloodstream. It's been navigating your cardiovascular system, and right now I've attached it to your left ventricle.  A little trick I picked up from the Borg.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: Yeah, they're full of great ideas.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: I just stopped your heart for five seconds. It felt like an eternity, didn't it? Did you know that you can stop the human heart for up to ten minutes before the onset of brain damage?

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: No, I didn't know that.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: We learn something new about ourselves every day.  Now. Maybe I didn't make myself clear. It is very important that you tell me exactly what Captain Picard knows.

turns.speaker: LA FORGE
turns.text: I told you everything. You might as well just kill me right now.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Don't you think you're taking this a little too far, Number One?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: When we went to ancient Rome for Deanna's promotion, we threw her to the lions, remember?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Well, now that we're all aboard=8A  Number One, bring the ship before the wind.  Let's see what's out there.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Aye, aye, sir.  Take the wheel, Commander.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Imagine what it was like, Will. No engines, no computers, just the wind, the sea and the stars to guide you.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Bad food, brutal discipline.  No women.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Make it so.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: There's still no indication of why they attacked the station?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: We think they were looking for something- they practically tore the place apart.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Hmm,  Inform Starfleet Command. This could indicate a new Romulan threat in this sector.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: You want me to contact Starfleet?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Is there a problem?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Thank you, Number One.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: There is something else, Captain. One of the scientists, a Doctor Soran,has insisted on speaking with you.  I told him you were busy, sir, but he said it was absolutely imperative that he speak with you right away.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Understood. That will be all.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Sir, is there anything wrong?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: No. Thank you.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Report.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: A quantum implosion has occurred within the Amargosa star. All nuclearfusion is breaking down.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: How is that possible?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Maybe they're not out there.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: They're just trying to decide whether a twenty year-old Klingon Bird of Prey is any match for the Federation flagship.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: That's a pretty big margin of error.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Too big. How long until the ribbon arrives?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: I always thought I'd have a crack at this chair one day.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: You may still. Somehow I doubt this will be the last ship to carry the name Enterprise.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Captain, are you all right?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Yes. Fine. If you'll excuse me.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Counselor. What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Actually, I'm here to see if there's anything I can do for you.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Well, I appreciate your concern, but I'd rather not discuss it right now, thank you.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: I'm afraid I can't just leave it at that. The commanding officer of this ship is clearly distraught about something. As ship's counselor, it's my duty to-

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: As ship's counselor, it's your duty to know not only when you're needed but also when you're not.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: You can't fool an empath, Captain. I know exactly when I'm needed.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Well, with all due respect to your Betazoid senses, I prefer to be alone right now.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Very well. I suppose I could make out my weekly report to Starfleet Command without your input.  "Admiral Lusby, regarding the unusual behavior of Jean-Luc Picard: I find him increasingly irritable, remote and uncooperative. I recommend forced shore leave at a Starbase facility in order to-"

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: All right, all right. You've made your point.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Captain, Im sorry.  I know there were a lot of unresolved conflicts between you and your brother.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: What I can't get out of my mind is the image of Rene- my nephew. I just can't believe he's gone.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: It's only natural to feel a heightened sense of tragedy when a child dies.  But it goes deeper than that, doesn't it? I can sense that Rene meant a great deal to you.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: In a way, he was as close as I ever came to having a child of my own.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Your family history is very important to you, isn't it?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Ever since I was a little boy, I remember hearing about the family line. The Picards that fought at Trafalgar, the Picards that settled the first Martian colony. When my brother married and had a son...

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: You felt it was no longer your responsibility to carry on the family line.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: My brother had shouldered that burden, allowing me to pursue my own selfish needs.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: There's nothing selfish about pursuing your own life, your own career.

turns.speaker: TROI
turns.text: Or perhaps they're on the surface.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Mr. Data, scan the planet for lifeforms.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Doctor Soran?

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Yes, yes, Captain. Thank you for coming.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Nothing for me.  I understand there's something urgent you need to discuss with me.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Yes. I need to return to the observatory immediately. I must continue a critical experiment I was running on the Amargosa star.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Doctor, we're still conducting an investigation into the attack. Once we've completed our work, we'll be happy to allow you and your fellow scientists back aboard the observatory. Until then-

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: The timing is very important on my experiment- if it is not completed within the next twelve hours, years of research will be lost.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: We're doing the best we can. Now if you'll excuse me...

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: You must think I'm quite the madman.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: The thought had crossed my mind.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: The only possible reason you're here is because you're not entirely confident you can shoot down my probe after all. So you've come to dissuade me from my horrific plan.  Good luck.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: I've spent eighty years looking for another way, Captain. This is the only one.  Of course, you could always come with me. You fancy yourself an explorer. Here's a chance to explore something no human has ever experienced.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Not if it means killing over two hundred million people.  I wonder, did your wife Leandra know that she married a man who was capable of mass murder?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: We're all mortal, Soran. It's one of the truths of ou existence.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: What if I told you I found a new truth?

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: The Nexus.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Time has no meaning there. The predator has no teeth.

turns.speaker: SORAN
turns.text: Careful, Captain. That's a fifty gigawatt forcefield. I wouldn't want to see you get hurt.

turns.speaker: PICARD
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: The royal...studs?

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: You see the top yardarm, now look to the-

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: It looks like we're too late.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: There are no other ships in the system.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: These blast patterns are consistent with Type III disruptors.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Well, that narrows it to Klingon, Breen or Romulan.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: One of the dead Romulans had a tricorder. We analyzed its sensor logs and found they were scanning for signature particles of a compound called trilithium.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Trilithium?

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: An experimental compound the Romulans have been working on. In theory, a trilithium-based explosive would be thousands of times more powerful than an anti-matter weapon. But they never found a way to stabilize it.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Why were they looking for it on a Federation observatory? It doesn't make any sense.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Have Geordi and Data go over with the next Away Team. Tell them to scan the observatory for trilithium.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: Aye, sir.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: Sensor records show a solar probe was launched from the observatory a few moments ago.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: The star's going to collapse in a matter of minutes.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: I have spoken to the Klingon High Council, sir. They identified the Bird of Prey as belonging to the Duras sisters.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Lursa and B'Etor? This doesn't make any sense. A renowned stellar physicist somehow uses a trilithium probe to destroy a star, kidnaps Geordi and escapes with a pair of Klingon renegades. Why? What the hell's going on?

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: They have found a way to penetrate our shields.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Lock phasers and return fire!

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: It is a Class D-12 Bird of Prey. They were retired from service because of defective plasma coils.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Plasma coils...is there any way we can use that to our advantage?

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: I do not see how. The plasma coil is part of their cloaking device.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: As their cloak begins to engage, their shields will drop.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Right. And they'll be vulnerable for at least two seconds.  Data,lock onto that plasma coil.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: Worf, prepare a spread of photon torpedoes. We'll have to hit them the instant they begin to cloak.

turns.speaker: WORF
turns.text: Aye, sir.

turns.speaker: RIKER
turns.text: We're only going to get one shot at this. Target their primary reactor. With any luck, their warp core should implode.

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: Status!

turns.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
turns.text: All automates ready and functioning. Automatic moorings retracted. All speeds available through transwarp drive.

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: Incredible machine. Helmsman, one-quarter impulse power.

turns.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
turns.text: Enterprise maintaining full impulse power...

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: And we are gaining... Stand by, tractor beam!

turns.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
turns.text: Tractor beam, aye!

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: If he tries to get away with Warp Drive, he's really in for a shock...

turns.speaker: 1ST OFFICER
turns.text: Transwarp at your command, Sir!

turns.speaker: STYLES
turns.text: Execute!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Steady... Steady, boys. Keep scanning...  I thought you people were reliable... Where the hell is he!

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: He has been here for some time. I can feel his presence.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Don't give me your Klingon mumbo- jumbo -- there ain't another vessel in this whole damn quadrant.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Put me on the hailing frequency.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Sure - whatever games you wanna play.

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: What's going on? When do we get paid off...?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Soon, Captain... Quite soon.

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Mr. Chekov -- ?

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: An energy reading from 'C" deck -- from inside Mr. Spock's quarters...

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: Mr. Chekov, I ordered Spock's quarters sealed!

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Yes, sir, I sealed the room myself. Nevertheless -- I am reading a life form there.

turns.speaker: CHEKOV
turns.text: Will we get another ship?

turns.speaker: KIRK
turns.text: I can't get an answer. Starfleet is up to its brass in galactic conference. No one has time for those who only stand... and wait.
